column10: Walmart built a warehouse on top of sacred land near Teotihuacan's Moon Pyramid despite public outcry, and there is evidence Walmart bribed government officials to change the building codes to allow this. In 2019, they finally paid a fine equivalent to 0.05% of their revenue for that year for admiting to violating federal anti-bribery law in Brazil, yet are still allowed to operate there. In 2017, Walmart contributed to the labor abuse of 4 toy manufactorers in China affecting workers with low wages, excessive overtime, dangerous work environments and poor living conditions. In India, fabric is sourced from mills using forced child labour. Scored 2nd to worst in mineral mining practices for jewelry retail. Landed on 2018's top 10 corporate Criminals list for its treatment of employees and enabling of gender-based violence on workers in garment supplier factories in Asia. Scored 18.7/100 on its IPE Green Supply Chain practices, and is one of the world's worst plastic polluters. Scored 39% on the Forest 500 company rankings. If not sustainably sourced, palm oil is harvested from Bornean rainforests, which causes the destruction of Orangutan habitat. In this case, Walmart scored a sustainable palm oil source rating of 13.3/22, which is average. Major plastic polluter. Sources unsustainable cotton. 22.7% on Corporate Human Rights Benchmark.

Amazon has a severely low Forest 500 rating (9%), rates a tier 5 on the 2019 Business Benchmark on Farm Animal Welfare Report (BBFAW) meaning they provide little evidence they are making strides to manage animal welfare in their practices. They have a 16/100 on the S&P global sustainability report and are identified as a company using Uyghur forced labor in China. Amazon has a  low transparency about e-waste and fails to publish restrictions on hazardous chemicals in its devices. They score a 10-20% ranking on Corporate Human Rights Benchmark (CHRB), and have low risk-managaement in global mineral mining and the workers involved, numerous lawsuits involving labor rights and have comitted tax avoidance.

Walgreens has been making improvements towards sustainability with their recent largescale initiatives to reduce their carbon footprint by 15.3% in 2019. and diverted 93% of their waste from distribution facilities, much of it being safe, unused toiletries, food, and household items donated to Feeding America. Provides free and safe pharmaceutical waste disposal so the drugs do not affect fish and wildlife, which often causes hormone disruptions and reproductive ability downstream via bioaccumulation. Walgreens does test some of their products on animals, and sells cruelty-free and vegan items as well. They recently stopped doing business with coconut milk brands Aroy-D and Chaokoy that were found to abuse monkeys to collect their coconuts. Allegations of ethics law violations and breaches in prescription data.

Ikea is an accredited living wage employer but has poor supply chain management practices. Their environmental reports are not independently verified, and their sourcing of cotton is not transparent. They source factory farmed meat and leather, but have vowed to not use live-plucked feathers for their down material and have increased their plant-based options at their eateries. FSC (Forest Stewardship Council) certified, uses recycled and certified FSC wood, and has made much in strides for their sustainability practices, but their FSC certification has been revoked before and recent reports say they have been using illegally sourced beech wood from Ukraine. IKEA's practices are more in line with fast-furniture, forgoing some ethical practices to produce on a mass scale. IKEA uses two subsidaries that are high-risk for tax-avoidance. Pledged to reach a circular waste model by 2030, and reduced its Carbon footprint by 15% in 2019. If not sustainably sourced, palm oil is harvested from Bornean rainforests, which causes the destruction of Orangutan habitat. In this case, IKEA scored a sustainable palm oil source rating of 19/22, which is well above average.

Gap uses Uygur slave labor and fails to pay minimum living wage to any worker making their products. They scored a 35.4% on its human rights performance related to sourcing conflict minerals. Contributes to Bangladeshi garment labor abuse. Fails to provide evidence of ethical and sustainable cotton sourcing. Gap sources animal products of leather, wool and exotic animal hair, and does not use fur, down or exotic animal skin, along with banning use of Angora. Gap is a member of the Alliance for Bangladesh Worker Safety, and Make Fashion Circular program. They also place on the Gender-Equality Index (GEI) as a company seeking to improve their transparency with reporting gender-based data such as gender discrimination, equal pay, and sexual harassment reporting.

Zara is a fast-fashion giant with a business model that prioritizes heavy micro-seasonality with new weekly arrivals. Evidence shows Zara uses Uygur slave labor, and fails to pay minimum living wage to workers. In India, fabric is sourced from mills using forced child labour. Zara scored a (41-50%) Fashion Transparency rating. That being said, Inditex (a fashion group that owns Zara) began a "Close the Loop" program vowing to send nothing to landfills in 2023. This program seeks to exclusively use a circular model to recycle its clothing. As far as animal welfare, Zara does not use fur, angora, and products tested on animals, but does use untraced wool, leather, down, and exotic animal hair. Rates a 2.5/19.5 by WWF's cotton sourcing and traceablility practices, and a 30% on the Forest 500 ranking. They also place on the Gender-Equality Index (GEI) as a company seeking to improve their transparency with reporting gender-based data such as gender discrimination, equal pay, and sexual harassment reporting.

H&M uses Uygur slave labor and fails to pay minimum living wage to workers. They contribute to child labor in Bangladesh, and in India, fabric is sourced from mills using forced child labour. Relies on labor in Cambodia where labor rights are often violated in their manufactoring process. Better Cotton Initiative and Sustainable Apparel Coalition member, and partners with the MacArthur Foundation to transtition to a circular economy.  Recieved a 39% in 2019's Forest 500 rating that analyzes practices their impact on tropical forest commodities. Rated a D Carbon Disclosure Project's Forests Score, which scores transparency in how their practices are working to avoid deforestation in their supply chain. Cruelty free, fur-free, uses RDS (Responsible Down Standard)-certified down, bans Angora, and PETA-vegan-approved for their vegan collections. Scored a 24% on 2019's Human Rights Benchmark.
Romwe is a fast-fashion giant with extremely poor transparency about how their practices affect others downstream. Considered a "Fast-Fashion brand to avoid at all costs."

Fails to pay minimum living wage to workers, scored a 55/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index, which is above average. Participates in The Apparel and Footwear Supply Chain Transparency Pledge. Earned a B grade in mitigating against the risks of worker exploitation in their supply chains from Ethical Fashion Report. Fur-free, banned Angora use. Better Cotton Initiative member

Target rates in the 20-30% range for Corporate Human Rights Benchmark with a poor rating for transparency. They showed poor handling of the 2013 mass data breach and still have not effectively solved the issue that caused it, and has poor workplace ethical guidelines for employees that in 2015 resulted in a fatality and lawsuit. Although our rating is for Target's ethics themselves, some of the most ethical brands Target sells are Method, Burt's Bees, Annie’s Homegrown, TOMS, and Evol. Plans to phase out of mulesed wool (wool removed with the sheep's skin) by 2023. Claims their brand Up&Up is Cruelty-free, but provides no transparency about their animal practices. Does not allow employees to unionize. If not sustainably sourced, palm oil is harvested from Bornean rainforests, which causes the destruction of Orangutan habitat. In this case, Target scored a sustainable palm oil source rating of 9/22, which is poor.

Forever 21 has been guilty of widespread labor violations in Los Angeles Fashion District's sweatshops.They scored a 7/100 in the Fashion Transparency Index, and were found to irresponsibly source rayon, viscose, and other tree-based fabrics for their apparel. Forever 21 received an D- rating in Ethical Fashion Report and have banned the use of fur and Angora in their production. They additionally have a program to recycle used clothing to prevent them being sent to the landfill.

Lululemon rates a 13/100 on the Global ESG score that measures sustainability practices, and a 24% on the 2019 Corporate Human Rights Benchmark. They are a BlueSign member, Leaping Bunny Certified, fur-free, and uses RDS-certified down. Lululemon has been sourcing clothing from a factory in Bangladesh where women regularly experience physical violence, humiliation, and other abuses from their managers.Sustainable Apparel Coalition and Textile Exchange member working on reducing Lululemon's environmental and social impact. They also place on the Gender-Equality Index (GEI) as a company seeking to improve their transparency with reporting gender-based data such as gender discrimination, equal pay, and sexual harassment reporting.

Nike uses Uygur slave labor, has several human rights violations, and fails to pay minimum living wage to workers. They rely on production facilities in Cambodia that abuse their garment workers. Earned a 32% rating on Forest 500, a D- on the Carbon Disclosure Project's rating. In 2019 they became a Responsible Minerals Initiative member, but scored a 46% on performance in sourcing minerals in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Scored the lowest rating in Ethical Consumer's tax avoidance. Made a commitment to zero discharge of hazardous chemicals by 2020. Bluesign member. Does not use fur, and is a member of the Working Leather Group that ensures compliance in tannery practices, however they do not have a clear animal welfare policy for their business practices. Became a core partner in 2019 for the Make Fashion Circular initiative. Became a Better Work partner in 2020 to improve working conditions in the garment industry. Scored a 24% on the Human Rights Benchmark. They also scored a 100% for LGBT workplace equality,

Adidas uses Uygur slave labor and fail to pay minimum living wage to workers. In 2019, they recieved an A rating in the Ethical Fashion Report, a 92/100 in the KnowTheChain Benchmark, but a 24% in the Human Rights Benchmark. They did score a 69% (above averge, since the highest score was 73%) in the Fashion Transparency Index, signifying that Adidas publishes highly detailed supplier lists and policies. Adidas received a B rating for the Carbon Discosure Project's analysis. Scored 2nd place in the 2020 Global 100 Most Sustainable Corporations in the World list, but simultaneously scored a 27% for the Forest 500 ranking for their timber use. They have also contributed to worker abuse issues in Camboidia by relying on their factories for their supply chain. They ban angora use, and are a Leather Working Group member. They also are a program member of the Make Fashion Circular initiative.

Everlane appears to greenwash many of their products, as they scored a 30/100 on Remake's Sustainable Brand criteria. They claim to be transparent but fail to explain their wages paid to workers and their raw material sourcing. They lack certifications proving they pay fair wages, and source from countries that are high-risk for labor abuse. They do however make their denim jeans at Sai-Tex, one of the most sustainable denim factories in the world, yet the rest of their clothing is unaccounted for. They do make their "sustainable" clothing accessible by having lower prices, and advocate to go "no new plastic" by 2021 but not plastic-free. Everlane Donated 100% profits from Black Friday to environmental organization Oceana, and their leather is audited by the Leather Working Group. Everlane uses animal products (leather, wool, exotic animal hair). Their lack of third-party verification means they aren't held accountable with the claims they make. Everlane was also accused legitimately of union busting, where they laid off most workers who tried to unionize for Covid. Their "radical transparency" claim is more akin to "convenient transparency", and they are accused of anti-Black toxic workplace behavior.
Vibram uses sustainable soles in their shoes, are vegan friendly, and removed from sales from Amazon.
Nintendo uses Uyghur child labor, has poor e-recycling practices, and scored a low labor rights ranking.

Gamestop incorporated customer trickery in their practices to make money and has a few labor lawsuits filed against them. They do however have a good game recycling/upcycling program to prevent used games from going into the landfill.

Petsmart has been responsible for many animal deaths at the hands of groomers and exotic animal trade and has poor labour conditions. They do fund a foundation for support-animals for people with disability.

Jolyn is slow-fashion, uses sustainable fabric, made in USA (yet source of labor TBD), partners with local charities, vegan, and fibers include no animal-based by-products. They donated $20k to BLM, practice model diversity and platforms Black aquatic athletes. However they are not fully body inclusive in their sizing.

Macy's has a low human rights benchmark rating, and a Fashion Transparency Index score of 16/100. The Macy's Day Parade is unsustainable with reckless Helium use. They are making strides in corporate solar panel energy usage, working on diversification, and will stop selling and storing fur by 2021. Macy's also has a GoFundMe "shop for a cause" charity.
BLK+GRN uses sustainable eco-packaging, are Black-owned social advocates and engage in activism, are a cruelty-free, plant-based, small business, and platforms artisans who have ethical practices.

Titleist makes their products in their factory in the USA. Golf balls last basically forever as opposed to single-use golf balls, but aren't biodegradable and often get lost outdoors. Titelist does not use animal products but there is little information on this, and golf balls adversely affect wildlife when lost.

FashionNova is a Fast-fashion company, and uses Los Angeles sweat shops to make their clothing which disenfranchises workers. They contribute to over 92 million tons of clothing into the landfill annually, and have numerous labor violations. They do have a vegan collection for those who wish to avoid animal products.
Get Lost Perv! does not share information about their business practices online. With little transparency and no data available online, this is rated a 5.0 until further notice.
Knotty Knickers does not share information about their business practices online. With little transparency and no data available online, this is rated a 5.0 until further notice.
Milky Syrup does not share information about their business practices online. With little transparency and no data available online, this is rated a 5.0 until further notice.
iiii Clothing does not share information about their business practices online. With little transparency and no data available online, this is rated a 5.0 until further notice.
Bad Habits does not share information about their business practices online. With little transparency and no data available online, this is rated a 5.0 until further notice.
Belayered does not share information about their business practices online. With little transparency and no data available online, this is rated a 5.0 until further notice.

Cheekbone Beauty donates 10% of their profits to Shannen’s Dream, a charity that supports First Nations youth education, does not test on animals, has all vegan products, Indigenous-owned, working to eliminate single-use plastics, hires Indigenous employees, supports Native labor and economy, and uses zero-waste innovation.
Fragrance Net does not share information about their business practices online. With little transparency and no data available online, this is rated a 5.0 until further notice.
Foreflight does not share information about their business practices online. With little transparency and no data available online, this is rated a 5.0 until further notice.
Fashion Brand is slow-fashion, uses reusable packaging, works with international fair-trade co-ops, woman-owned and run, pays artisans fair wage, body size-inclusive, gender-inclusive, and vegan.
Harbor Freight shares their policies on being against using human trafficking and slave labor to make their products and has an extensive donation program, but is in ligation with manager labor.
Tee Public supports independent artists, uses biodeegradable ink, is vegan, gIves back to charities, has body-inclusive options, and has good GlassDoor reviews for labor.

Girlfriend Collective has an extensive recycling program (clothing is recyclable and buys back clothes to make new ones), uses  materials made in a zero-waste facility that guarantees fair wages, is size inclusive (XXS - 6XL), SA8000-Certified (like FairTrade for textiles), upcycles BPA-free waterbottles to make material, are anti-child labor, and vegan.

Deciem ships their products in Carbon-neutral boxes from offsets purchased from CarbonZero, and for brick-and-mortar recycled paper bags, takes back empty packaging and uses progressive waste management program to reduce the fate of products ending up in the landfill. They are very transparent, do not test on animals, are cruelty-free, and resisted black friday sales last year to not enable over-consumption on their platform. Has a poor rating on Glassdoor describing the working condition reviews from employees, have donated to Black Lives Matter, and gave paid leave for employees protesting for George Floyd.

Yes Style is fast-fashion, ships in plastic wasteful packaging, has no indication they intend to be transparent or support human or animal welfare, but recognized as a "Caring Company" from Hong Kong Council of Social Service.
Peach & Lily is a cruelty-free/vegan shop, and has a mentorship program to support Black aestheticians

Hair Story uses biodegradable packaging, has an extensive refill system to reduce plastic consumption by 91%, is a 1% for the Planet partner, cruelty-free, but not completely vegan (uses keratin derived from sheeps wool).

Innisfree uses an eco-recycling program for empty containers to be upcycled into other merchandise. They participate in the Eco-Handkerchief Campaign, which gifts hankies with purchase, but are not cruelty-free.
Spectrum Boutique is woman-owned, body-inclusive, gender non-conforming, and advocates for sex-education.
Dumbgood does not share information about their business practices online. With little transparency and no data available online, this is rated a 5.0 until further notice.

LL Bean uses Uyghur slave labor, scores a 6/100 on transparency, are compliant with Responsible Down Standard (RDS), part of the Bangladesh Worker Safety Alliance, a Sustainable Apparel Coalition member, a Textile Exchange member, a BlueSign partner, but has low transparency about social welfare.

Soft charms are not a fast fashion company, but has little transparency thus far and are a relatively smaller business. No outstanding critisism found, so we give a 5.0 rating until further information can be found.

The NBA Store is taking measures for sustainability and upcycling of unsold jerseys into 7,000 masks, are a member of the Green Sports Alliance, have a code of conduct for labor practices publicly available, and won the Community Assist Award for 2019. However they have very low transparency, and rate a 6.2 /10 on Glassdoor for their labor and work culture. They have a line of recycled jerseys from plastics, but these often contribute to microplastics in the ocean. They are additionally in the process of transitioning to vegan/vegetarian foods at games and players are going vegan/vegetarian to help divest from animal agriculture. NBA jerseys are made by Adidas, who we score a 6.0.

Blueland has a strong environmental mission, platinum material health certificate from Cradle to Cradle, sells no-waste and no-plastic packaging, vegan and cruelty-free, and is leaping-bunny certified. They use glass to reduce plastic waste, but glass can be environmentally costly to transport. Their vendors are in compliance with the Business Social Compliance Initiative (BSCI), and they are in process of B Corp certification. Blueland pays employees for political and civic engagement and requires implicit bias training for new hires.

HiBar is a cruelty-free and vegan company that uses eco-friendly packaging, compostable/recyclable packaging, and does not use palm oil. Their bars are biodegradable. They appreciate diversity in their models, and commit to diversity on social media. They claim they are solidifying certifications for labor practices and diversity, but haven't finished yet. They are also Carbon-neutral through partnership with the Southern Plains Land Trust.

Victoria's Secret does not source eco-friendly materials, show little evidence of seeking improvement in environmental and labor practices, and doesn't use animal products except silk but tests on animals. There are also allegations of fatphobia, transphobia, lack of diversity, and child labor use. Contributes to pollution in China, uses Uyghur slave labor, and scores low on the Fashion Transparency Index at a 21/100.

Pink is progressing their sustainability initiatives, is a Better Cotton Initiative member, a member of the JED foundation for teen mental health, donated $50k to the Human RIghts Campaign, $200k to the Feeding America Foundation, and $1 million to the National Urban League. They are an American Forests partner, and Her Next Play supporter. Their products are not cruelty-free and they source from Uyghur slave labor.
Newegg shows no evidence of environmental responsibility, and has allegations of using underpaid labor. They are a somewhat better alternative to Amazon, but still poor in ethical practices.

Lucy & Yak are a living-wage employer and pay 4x state minimum wage in North India. They were an award finalist for Draper's Sustainable Fashion, and are mostly vegan (uses recycled wool for winter coats). All postage material and stationary is 100% recycled and biodegradable, and they make some fashion lines out of recycled plastic. They are a 12 months climate-positive workforce from planting over 10,000 trees, and donated to an organization for access to menstruation supplies.

Coco Clem supports diversity, body positivity and gender-inclusivity through the options available in their apparel. They make each item to order to avoid wasteful overproduction, made in the USA by one designer, and all swimwear is made from 100% recyclable polyester that is third party certified with Oeko-Tex's Standard 100, use non-toxic, water based inks and ship in compostable packaging. They use a fabric recycling program that allows their fabric to be diverted from the landfill. Use no animal by-products. Donated over 500 handmade masks to: Black Lives Matter, Latino Alliance UNCW, Good Samaritan Hospital, The Medical Center of Aurora, Pediatric Behavioral Center, Wave Transit, Food Lion, Harris Teeter, Dollar General, and Templo Adoracion Y Alabanza.

Orenda Tribe is an Indigenous-owned company that handmakes items from restored and repurposed vintage and upcycled textiles. They are against fast fashion, and include Native artisans from Dinétah. Orenda Tribe founded the Dził Asdzáán (Mountain Woman) Command Center, a collective of Diné matriarchs that have provided meals, reusable masks, PPE and hand sanitizer for Diné relatives. They also hosted the SPREAD LOVE + SHINE LIGHT auction in which 100% of the proceeds go to the work of the Command Center. They also initiated the Children of Nááts'íilid heart project that support Diné children and the Amá Dóó Áłchíní Bíghan domestic abuse shelter. They also work on initiatives for Indigenous land reclamation and  protection for Chaco Canyon. May use recycled leather, wool, exotic animal hair and silk in their upcycled clothing, but does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin or angora or otherwise new animal byproducts.
Sweet Street Cosmetics is a cruelty-free, non animal testing brand but are not vegan. WOC-owned. They have not shared information about their environmental, social or labor impacts.

Alpine Butterfly Swim is an all women-owned brand that makes suits made-to-order to prevent wasteful over-production. Their brand focuses on body positivity, empowerment, and self love, making swimwear accessible to plus-sized shoppers. They have model diversity on their website. Alternately, the brand is not very transparent about their labor practices, environmental impact or animal byproduct usage.

Wolven uses eco-friendly, locally sourced materials to make activewear from recycled water bottles and modal (a type of fiber from beachwood pulp). They're vegan, and certified with a score of 87% by the Workplace Conditions Assessment which ensures fair working conditions. They are Carbon-Neutral certified. Partners with Cancel Plastic, who hire collectors to source ocean-bound plastic water bottles from polluted areas of Port-Au-Prince, Haiti. Wolven are currently committing 10% of net profits to the COVID-19 LA County Response Fund.

Made Trade is a woman and POC-owned marketplace of hand-selected ethical products that are: Sustainable (Made with earth-friendly materials that are responsibly harvested or upcycled); Fair trade (Handmade by artisans adhering to fair labor practices); Heritage (Crafted by hand using traditional techniques); USA-Made: (Made by U.S. makers, but does not negate the possibility of in-country labor abuse); and Vegan (Free of animal materials and animal byproducts). They donate to 1% for the Planet, and have a Carbon-Neutral checkout process.

Anthropologie rates a 0-10% on the 2019 Fashion Transparency Index, resulting from their lack of animal welfare policy and evidence that their supply chain operates in any ethical manner. They lack third party verification in their labor standards or living-wage practices. As of September 28, 2020, Urban Outfitters Inc. and their flagship stores (Anthropologie & Free People) are under investigation for their abuse of alpacas for their fur. Anthropologie has also been accused of racial profiling by salespeople, and not paying Black content creator Lydia Okello for their work.

Wish's cheap prices reflect the underpaid labor (and sometimes child labor) it takes to offer such low prices. Wish's marketplace sources from third-party distributers in China, where although labor laws are in place, they are often over-saught in favor of revenue from mass-sales. This also allows Wish to not be held accountable for any violations the occur from the products' production.

Urban Outfitters have been critisized for selling extremely distasteful shirts, such as a blood-stained Kent State shirt, shirts for kids that advocate alcohol consumption, holocaust-style tapestries, and color options titled "Obama/black". As of September 28, 2020, Urban Outfitters Inc. and their flagship stores (Anthropologie & Free People) are under investigation for their abuse of alpacas for their fur. They do not use fur, down, angora or exotic animal hair, but they do use untraceble leather and wool. Although they have an upcycled clothing line, their main line does not use adaquately sustainable materials. They also show little transparency (a 20% on the Fashion Transparency Index) and regarding their use of water and wastewater management. Additionally, their labor laws are often violated, most notably a scandal in which employees were asked to work for free for "training."

American Eagle Outfitters scored a 17/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index, which was below the average of 23%. They scored a 25% on their Green Supply Chain report, which evaluates their environmental supply chain practices in China. For their 2019 SAM Corporate Sustainability Assessment, AEO scored a 10/100, showing much work to be done in the way of their risk-management for sustainability and labor practices. Better Cotton Initiative member, Better Work partner, and Fashion Industry Charter for Climate Action signatory. American Eagle Outfitters use leather, down and exotic animal hair, and have banned their use of angora, fur, and exotic animal skin.

Although it is virtually impossible to rate particular shops on Etsy, we can assess their practices. Etsy gives clear rules to sellers: No Child or Youth Labor, No Involuntary or Slave Labor, Humane Working Conditions, and Non-Discrimination. However, regulation of these rules are not constant. In 2020, Etsy failed to remove the influx of shops selling handmade mesh masks that falsely advertised to protect shoppers from COVID-19, and Etsy may have caused risk to public health by failing to do so. Additionally, Etsy has partnered with 3Degrees to combat climate change by offsetting the Carbon footprint of their shipping packages. All in all, Etsy may be a better alternative to corporations that fail to pay their workers fairly as most Etsy shops are self-made goods, but the environmental cost of shipping, and the types of materials used in each product can affect its ethical impact. Exercise caution when perusing Etsy, and if you'd like our input on a specific product, please send us an email!

As of September 28, 2020, Urban Outfitters Inc. and their flagship stores (Anthropologie & Free People) are under investigation for their abuse of alpacas for their fur. They use leather, wool and exotic animal hair, but not down, angora or exotic animal skin.They scored a 35/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index, which is slightly above average. Claims to use eco-conscious materials such as Global Organic Textile Standard certified linen, hemp, cotton, Global Recycle Standard certified cotton, waterless-processed denim, and recycled knitwear. They operate in production in facilities running on 100% renewable energies and source from Fair Trade certified organizations.

Nordstrom scored a 67/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index. They have been critized to still be selling fur coats when most department stores have phased out of this practice. In December of 2019, PETA released an exposé of Nordstrom's sourcing from the Russian fur trade, in which the involved animals are abused and their regulations violated. Has made sustainability goals to reduce single-use plastic by 2025, but some of the other goals are non-quantitative and somewhat vague.

Starbucks is using renewable energy for 105% of its electricity use and has been identified as using best corporate practices for LGBT equality by the Human Rights Campaign. They are World Cocoa Foundation members committed to supporting sustainable cocoa sourcing, and Sustainable Agriculture Initiative members. Despite this, Starbucks scored an F in its 2019 Mind the Store report on using toxic chemicals from its consumer products, was rated in the 0-10% range for their Human Rights Benchmark, and were given a score of 15/100 on their supply chain practices in China. Starbucks also scored a 25/100 on the Forest 500 report, which checks for how their sourcing affects tropical rainforests, and were ranked as one of the world's worst plastic polluters. Starbucks also gets an F rating for their animal antibiotics use by the Natural Resources Defense Council, and fails to implement animal welfare implementation. Lastly, Starbucks has been titled as one of the worst tax-avoidance companies by Ethical Consumer.

Apple recieved an A rating on Greenpeace's Click Clean report, which monitors the environmental impact of its websites and apps. They also recieved an A rating for the Carbon Disclosure Project which analyzes how they disclose climate change risks in their practices, and are a Green Power Partner with the EPA. Scored a 5/7 in preventative child labor practices. Apple has been identified as using best corporate practices for LGBT equality by the Human Rights Campaign. That being said, Apple also has been found to use Uygur slave labor, and expose its workers to benzene, a carcinogen. Since then Benzene has been banned in its supply chain, but not in subcontracting positions that make up 2/3 of it's manufactoring. Apple has been identified in 2019 as a company assisting the Burmese military to commit human rights violations and environmental destruction against its people, and Apple supports apps for companies the Burmese military owns, such as Mytel. Apple's low repairability capability makes it difficult for users to afford repair, and makes it harder for marginalized communities to have access to their devices in favor of revenue earned from forcing users to buy a new product when something goes wrong, which also adds to e-waste. Apple was also identified as high-risk for tax avoidance. Identified as not exploiting animals, but still uses leather for its wristbands and watches.

Thrive Market is Global Animal Partnership certified, offers fast and free Carbon-neutral shipping and free membership to veterans, students, and struggling families. Their warehouses are zero-waste, and the company offers a variety of vegan and cruelty-free products. The Thrive Market COVID-19 Relief Fund raised $90,000 in donations.

Carrefour scored a 20/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index, and does not provide much information about its ethical practices. It also scored a 25/100 on the Corporate Human Rights Benchmark. They additionally scored a sustainable palm oil source rating of 12.8/22. If not sustainably sourced, palm oil is harvested from Bornean rainforests, which causes the destruction of Orangutan habitat.

Matt & Nat are well known for their vegan handbags, in which they use recycled nylon, cork, rubber, plastic bottles and bike tires. However, the most commonly used materials used are polyurethane and polyvinyl chloride, or PVC, one of the most environmentally harmful plastics as well as high-risk to workers manufactoring with it. Matt & Nat has also been critisized for exaggerating their green claims. They are SA800-certified for their labor practices, but show little transparency about how these policies are enforced, and how their manufactoring process occurrs.

Sears has very low transparency about their business practices. They have released some environmental reports, however in light of their bankruptcy and closing it is difficult to know for sure what their practices are like this year.

Boohoo fails to pay minimum living wage to workers, and scored a 9/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index. They have been critisized for misleading advertising in which they claimed a jumper was faux fur, but tested and discovered to be from real animal fur. Recieved a C- grade in the Ethical Fashion Report.

Mango scored a 5/100 on the Corporate Information Transparency Index which analyzes supply chain practices. They scored a 22/100 in the Fashion Transparency Index as well. In 2019, the signed onto the Bangladesh Safety Accord to support worker safety and labor rights. They use some eco-friendly materials like organic cotton.

Kohl's was named one of Ethisphere's most ethical companies of 2020, but this seems to be based off of corporate factors, and this information conflicts with other data avalable and having a severely low Human Rights Benchmark score of 0-10%, and having a score of 16/100 with the Fashion Transparency Index.
No data available, little transparency

The Home Depot's plastic supplier is being sued over using unpaid, forced inmate labor. In May of 2020, forest protectors protested The Home Depot and FSC logging and herbicide application at Rainbow Ridge, a high conservation value forest. (Not included in the score but may be good to know: boycotts have been formed against The Home Depot for their co-founder's support and donating to the Trump 2020 campaign, and $7 million to Trump's 2016 presidential run).

Lowe's has a 2.4/5 rating for labor reviews, and ignited controversy by pulling ads from 'All-American Muslim' program. They are incorporating "Smart Irrigation" technology and taking sustainability measures in their store energy use.

Alibaba's low transparency makes it difficult to understand from an ethical perspective, however it is widely acknowledged that the company is comparable to Amazon and exploits laborers by promoting excessive overtime culture in favor of corporate revenue.

Seven & I scored a 10/100 on the Forest 500 report., a 10-20% on the Human Rights Benchmark, and a 28.9% on the Newsweek Green Ranking. They also scored the lowest ranking for their animal welfare practices on the 2019 Business Benchmark.

TJ Maxx scored a 15/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index, and sources their materials from sweatshops that pay their workers only $4/hour. They scored a 90% on the the Human Rights Campaign's Corporate Equality Index.

Ebay scored an A- on the Carbon Disclosure Project, an initiative that asks brands to disclose how they are taking measures to mitigate climate change risk. They scored a B at ClickClean.org, which analyzes the energy footprint of companies' online presence and encourages this to be sourced from renewable energy. Ebay also scored a 100% on the Human Rights Campaign's Corporate Equality Index, and scored 63/100 on the 2019 SAM Corporate Sustainability Assessment. In contrast, Ebay was found to likely use  tax avoidance strategies with the worst rating by Ethical Consumer, and Ebay's CEO, Devin Wenig, was ranked #88 on USA's most overpaid CEOs. CEO overpayment negatively affects the companies, employes, customers, economy, and society.

Costco scored a 15/100 on 2020's Fashion Transparency Index, and a 0-10% range score on the Corporate Human Rights Benchmark. They got a "red" rating for their tuna sourcing which means the company fails to sustainably source tuna in a way that allows populations to rebound the next harvest season. Costco recieved an F rating for their paper tissue sourcing by Natural Resources Defense Council and Stand.earth, a 16.6/100 by Greenpeace for failing to address the plastic pollution crisis in their manufactoring processes, and ranked as one of the world's worst plastic polluters in 2018. Costco has been identified as a company using Uyghur forced labor in China. Costco received a score of 7.5/120 for their rating on failing to develop a conflict-free mining process in the Congo. They also recieved an 18/100 on the Corporate Sustainability Assessment, a 27/100 with Forest 500, and received a D rating from the Carbon Disclosure Project, an initiative that asks brands to disclose how they are taking measures to mitigate climate change risk. Costco received a 23/100 on their efforts to address forced labour and human trafficking in their supply chains.

McDonald's was scored a 24% for their animal welfare practices by World Animal Protection. They have had multiple labor rights violation lawsuits and racial discrimination, and were scored in the 20-30% range by the Corporate Human Rights Benchmark. If not sustainably sourced, palm oil is harvested from Bornean rainforests, which causes the destruction of Orangutan habitat. In this case, McDonald's scored a sustainable palm oil source rating of 13.8/22, which is below average.

Aldi scores a 30% by Forest 500, an organization that analyzes rainforest risk-management in company supply chains. Aldi's hen suppliers for eggs have densities of over 10,000 hens/hectare, almost 7x the maximum of free-range requirements. If not sustainably sourced, palm oil is harvested from Bornean rainforests, which causes the destruction of Orangutan habitat. In this case, Aldi scored a sustainable palm oil source rating of 18.3/22, which is above average. Their Business Benchmark on Farm Animal Welfare rating is a tier 2, meaning Aldi seeing animal welfare as "Integral to business strategy." They also scored a B- in the Ethical Fashion Report, which measures labor violations.

Best Buy uses an extensive free e-waste recycling program, with 85% waste diversion in 2020, and was named one of the Ethisphere's World's Most Ethical Companies list. They were also featured on the Climate Change A List, as a leading company on environmental transparency and performance. The company's Geek Squad also works with the FBI to report child sexual abuse found on computers taken in for repair.

Shein is a fast-fashion giant that does not share information about their business practices online, as their transparency is severely lacking. Fast-fashion brands rely on sweatshops using unsafe working conditions and child labor to make their prices lower, and do to their low-quality nature and high micro-seasonality contribute to being the second most polluting industry in the world.

Although Sephora is a cosmetic marketplace for many brands, this score reflects the practices of the company itself. Sephora's cosmetic brand is not cruelty-free, although they do sell cruelty-free and vegan cosmetics. Many cosmetic brands source Mica, a mineral used in most shimmery cosmetics, using childlabor. Most of Sephora's brands source their mica from these quaries, except for the brand Aether Beauty, which claims to use fair-trade Mica from France. Sephora claims to put sustainability "front and center," but reputable data is lacking in transparency.

Although Ulta is a cosmetic marketplace for many brands, this score reflects the practices of the company itself. Ulta's collection does not test on animals. Ulta has been accused of racial profiling and forcing employees to resell used cosmetics to shoppers.

About 40% of West Elm's product line is Fair-Trade Certified as of 2020, and uses engineered or reclaimed wood which is more energetically efficient and sustainable. They use animal products like sheepskin and leather in their products. According to EndSlavryNow, West Elm is a safe retailer of slavery-free products.

Wayfair lacks transparency in their practices. They have an Environmental, Social and Governance score of 2, which is below average. Wayfair has recently been criticized for doing business with migrant detention camps. They have also been criticized for lacking corporate ethics implementaion strategies in their supply chain.

Samsung uses Uygur Muslim slave labor, and scores within the 30-40% range on the Corporate Human Rights Benchmark. Samsung scored a 20.3/100 on the conflict minerals ranking, which scores a companies effort in responsibly mining from the Democratic Republic of the Congo.They received a D rating in ClickClean, which scores a companies online energy footprint. Their efforts to eliminate child labor practices in their manufacturing processes were weak. The repairability of their devices is also low, making it difficult for low-income communities to maintain access to their electronic goods.

Reveal plants a tree for every product sold on their website, which has donated over $110,000 dollars to American Forests and other non-profits. They made their products from eco-friendly materials like bamboo, cork, cruelty-free vegan leather, and post-consumer plastic bottles.

Confidence Swimwear is a size-inclusive (sizes 0-20) swimwear brand that uses eco-friendly materials like regenerated Nylon made from ocean-bound plastic bottles and fishing nets. They use their spare material to make masks so that it doesn't go to waste. Their Balinese tailors are paid above minimum wage, and work from the comfort of home with their own hours. These are progressive claims, however this information is only available on their website and not third-party certified.

Valfre donated $15,000 to the NAACP legal defense fund, are a Latina-owned business, and donated 10% of Earth Day sales to the Nature Conservancy. However, their transparency is not so great regarding where they source their materials. they also have an activist tee section which gives proceeds to various charities. They do not test on animals.

Parade underwear are made in Oeko-Tex certified and Sedex certified factories in China. Their products ship in minimal, compostable packaging. Their products are made of pre-consumer recycled nylon, and comply with the Global Recycled Standard. They have donated $12,000 to Planned Parenthood New York, and the Yellowhammer Fund in Alabama. They are also size inclusive (XS - 3XL), and are working to expand their sizes further. Parade's models are diverse, and they do not use animal products in their items.

Nestle has a notorious reputation for being one of the most corrupt corporations in the world, and is the target of the worlds longest running boycott. Nestle continuously breaches international marketing standards, most notably in their targeting of pregnant and breastfeeding women in which they spread false information and gave women in under-served communites week supplies of baby formula (enough to induce the termination of breastmilk production) so that the women were forced to buy more of Nestle's formula after their breasts no longer produced milk by the time the free supply was used. Nestle attempts to stake claim to community water resources across North America, destroying streams, aquifers and wildlife. They are the worlds 3rd most plastic polluter, are responsible for mass deforestation for cocoa and palm oil use which destroys the Orangutan habitat. They are one of the worst perpetrators of human rights violations including failing to stop child labor in their cocoa fields, and Brazilian slave labor on their cocoa plantations. They scored an 11.8/100 on ther supply chain practices in China. Nestle does test on animals. They also undermine local control of water supplies in communities, then promote sales of bottled water there to turn a profit, and have shown no evidence of addressing the findings of nanoparticles in their baby formula, which can bioaccumulate in children from infancy and pose a threat to human health. Additionally, Nestle grossly violated human rights and experiment laws by testing their baby formula on 75 premature babies in India. In 2015, Nestle rejected Baby Milk Action's 4-point plan (submitted in 2001) to address the boycott filed against them for their treatment of breastfeeding women and causing countless infant deaths. They alsopay only $200/year to pump fresh water out of Flint, Michigan while it's citizens still have no access to clean water.

Bare Soaps uses a sustainable business model that centers around economic, social, and environmental accountability. They use Rainforest Alliance certified palm oil, recycled/recyclable materials, compostable and plantable packaging, and are no-waste, except for the plastic lids on their mud masks. They offset the Carbon of every shipment with reforestation projects, and their ingredients are vegan except for their Jubilee Jam soap that contains goat milk. In 2016, they partnered with the Sundara Fund to repurpose used hotel soaps and employ women in India with 3x the minimum wage to supply antiseptic resources to children. The woman-owned and POC-owned business is run by a single person, and 20% of their proceeds are reinvested into their economic development programs in India and Uganda.

Vetta is a high-end, slow fashion capsule wardrobe brand that encourages shoppers to choose 5 items to mix-and-match to create 30 outfits per month. They source sustainable materials like organic cotton, package shipments in 100% recycled materials, and use 70% solar power in their eco-friendly USA factories. Vetta does not use animal products, and are certified with SA8000 (for factories in India), the Global Organic Textile Standard and People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA). There are no observable praises or concerns over their social ethics.

Tradlands makes claims of sustainability and eco-friendliness, but lacks transparency in how they do it. They pride their items on their long-lasting material, which if true does add to their sustainability and anti-fast fashion, however failing to provide this information has been interpreted by some as a form of greenwashing. The company is also not third party certified, so the claims they make cannot be held accountable.

Ocean Spray has been identified by the Sustainable Agriculture Initiative Platform in 2020 as the first major food company in the US to be certified 100% sustainable for their water conservation practices and using the whole cranberry to prevent excessive food waste. They do not use palm oil or BPA in their products. They are recognized by the Human Rights Campaign for their LGBT equality, and are a Social Accountability International member being held accountable for their working conditions and labor practices. Ocean spray includes a clear label with recycling instructions to consumers, which can help reduce plastic waste from the landfill. Ocean Spray did settle a $5.4 million class action lawsuit in June of 2020 for false advertisement that they did not use artificial flavors in some of their juices. Note: If cranberries are not grown organically, they are detrimental to waterways due to the heavy pesticide and fertilizer use sprayed into the bogs they are grown in. Luckily, Ocean Spray does sell some organic cranberry juices, however their usual products contribute to this issue.

Womn is a woman-owned, POC-owned, slow-fashion business that focuses on made-to-order clothes that are durable to prevent fashion waste, with recycled and natural fibers like organic cotton, tincel, and bamboo. Their facility is in Los Angeles, CA, and they are a vegan brand. WOMN claims their facilities are ethically certified but failed to transparently show which certifications those are. They ship in recycled and recyclable polyethylene bags. Unfortunately WOMN will be shutting down as of October 2, 2020.

Boka's products are vegan, not tested on animals, BPA-free, and made in the USA, Italy, and China. With every purchase, Boka partners with Surge, a water crisis and sanitation non-profit, to donate toothbrushes to people in neeed. They do not provide transparent information online about if their practices are eco-friendly or labor-friendly.

Multiplicity is a woman-owned business, and is run on their own with only one employee and founder. The clothing is made-to-order, which prevents fabric waste and promotes slow-fashion. She uses Econyl, a type of recycled fiber made from nylon, and does not use animal products.
Pela products are compostable and ship in plastic-free packaging. They're Climate Neutral certified, and donate to 1% for the Planet. They do not use animal products, and donate

Thinx sells reusable menstrual cycle underwear, which creates a sustainable and environmentally friendly option opposed to single-use period products. Thinx recently came under fire for their poor workplace culture and sexual harrassment claims against the CEO, but is now run under different ownership. The current Thinx company still lacks transparency about their labor practices, and fails to provide evidence that they source from ethical facilities free of labor rights violations. They do not use animal products. The crotch area of their panties recently tested positive for toxic chemicals, particularly PFAS, which even at very low levels is linked to cancer and fertility problems due to the absorbent nature of vaginal tissue. This is also problematic because Thinx claimed their underwear did not contain these toxins in their products. They do donate to other social rights organizations like the EveryBody program, but do not appear to be third-party certified to support their claims.

Human Kind is a bath & body brand focusing on zero-waste, ships in carbon-neutral packaging, and offsets their carbon impact with funding reforestation projects in Brazil and New Jersey. All of their products are cruelty-free, and all products except for their silk floss are vegan. They supply their palm oil from RSPO-certified and Fair-Trade certified manufacturers. Human Kind lacks transparency about their labor practices, and little information is available about their social involvement.

Joann fabrics store is a member of the Corporate Giving program, in which they donate a portion of their proceeds to nonprofits such as the Kids In Need Foundation, and donated 300 million masks for those in need. They scored a 6/10 on Glassdoor for their employee practices and corporate management rating. Joanne uses some animal products like silk, and does not share where their materials are sourced from. They also lack transparency in their environmental impact and labor practices.

Tomboyx sells underwear and apparel to people of all genders. They avoid most animal products except they do use wool. They operate in Oeko-tex 100 certified factories, which recycle at least 50% of their water use and pay their employees a living wage. They have a line of apparel made from MicroModal fabric which uses sustainably harvested Beechwood. Tomboyx appreciates diversity in their models, and is a seize-inclusive brand (XS-4X). They also have donated to several social justice initiatives like Black Lives Matter, ACLU, and Trans Women of Color Collective.

Il Makiage does not test on animals. They score a 6/10 on Glassdoor for their employee satisfaction. The company also sells the idea of maximalism to shoppers, and  ships in packaging with bold text "Minimalism is dead" and "there's no such thing as too much", encouraging hyper-consumption. Il Makiage lacks transparency about their environmental practices, product sourcing, and social involvement.

Fenty Beauty is a skincare brand praised for its products' skin tone diversity in the cosmetics industry. They do not test on animals, and sell refillable packaging, and ship in recycled and post-consumer materials. Fenty lacks transparency in their environmental impacts, labor practices and wage pay, and social involvement.
Fenty does not share information about their business practices online. With little transparency and no data available online, this is rated a 5.0 until further notice.

Pacsun lacks transparency in several factors such as where their materials are sourced, if they pay a living wage to their workers, and where their leather and wool are sourced from. They do have a sustainable eco-friendly collection called "Me to We," however it is unclear where these materials are sourced and how the workers on this line are treated as well. They claim to have a Conflict Minerals Report on their website, however the link leads nowhere and a current report cannot be found with a basic search engine. Pacsun is also not third-party certified by any organizations, meaning they aren't held accountable for the claims they make about labor practices and sustainability.

GLDN is a Washington handmade jewelry workshop praised for its customizable and size-inclusive jewelry. They donate 10% of their profits in their Giving Back program, have collections that donate up to 100% of the profits to organizations they partner with and show on their website, and pay their employees for 10 hours of volunteer work. 95% of GLDN's materials are sourced domestically, and 90% of the metals they use are recycled, meaning they do not mine new gold, rather they buy second-hand, which reduces the environmental impact of mining. Their pacing uses recycled materials, their items are made to order, and they recycle all of their scrap metals to prevent waste. Their materials do not involve any animal products. They do not include information about where exactly their 10% of non-recycled metals come from.

B. Yellowtail is an artisan collective that celebrates Indigenous storytelling through wearable fashion. They are Native-owned and operated on Native land in North America, and employ with First Nations models, photographers, and poets to design and market their handmade clothing. They fundraised $6000 for the No-DAPL and womens' rights movements. They make their items b traditional sustainable means and use deadstock fabrics, which are reused second-hand to reduce waste and carbon impact. B. Yellowtail also partners with the Decolonizing Wealth Project to donate masks to Tribal communities who have been devastated by Covid-19. They use leather and decorative feathers in their items.

The Childrens place lacks public transparency in their practices, and likewise scored a 9/100 by the 2020 Fashion Transparency Index. In 2019, the CEO was paid 1262 times the amount of a median employee, while the company furloughed a majority of their workforce for the Covid-19 pandemic. They source from countries with high labor violation risk, including the Rana Plaza factory in Bangladesh that collapsed in 2013 and killed at least 1,134 workers. They became a Better Cotton Initiative member in 2019, and a member of the Bangladesh Worker Safety Alliance in 2020. They also are a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition and AFIRM group. They do not use any animal products.

Flamingos Life is a vegan, biodegradable sneaker store that operates and sources locally in Spain. Their shoes are made using materials like corn waste, bamboo, hemp, organic cotton, and sustainably extracted natural rubber. They also partner with other nonprofits to support clean ocean, water access and reforestation projects. They are also a BCOME member, which requires textile and apparel businesses to build efficient, sustainable and transparent supply chains under safe and ethical working conditions.

Bite toothpaste bits are plastic-free, cruelty-free and vegan. They ship in a refillable glass bottle, and recycled compostable post-consumer material. They offer refills shipped in compostable packages, which are lightweight as opposed to heavier glass refills. Little information is publicly available regarding their labor practices of social involvement.

Dieux Skin is small business praised for its reusable, vegan & cruelty-free alternative to single-use eyemasks. They ship in reusable and recyclable packaging, and keep their containers light and larger to reduce the Carbon impact of refills. They donate to organizations like Fair Fight to support voter re-infranchisement, and are a Floret Coalition member that supports anti-racism in the Cannabinoid industry. They are transparent about their prices, materials and practices.

Whimsy + Row is a small business of 10 employees that uses recycled, biodegradable and eco-friendly fabrics, environmentally friendly packaging, and conserves water in their supply chain. They use silk and leather in their products. Whimsy + Row makes their clothing locally. They have also taken steps to incorporate anti-racism in their supply chain.

Whole Foods is a globalized organic food retailer bought out by Amazon in 2017. Despite landing on Ethisphere's "World's Most Ethical Companies" Honoree list in previous years for their sustainability and "conscious corporate" demeanor, they did not make the list for the 2020-2021 year. If not sustainably sourced, palm oil is harvested from Indonesian rainforests, which causes the destruction of Orangutan habitat. In this case, Whole Foods scored a sustainable palm oil source rating from WWF of 8/22, which is poor, which conflicts with their website statement claiming 100% of their palm oil is sustainably harvested through RSPO. Recent lawsuit include claims of employee retaliation and selective enforcement for masks with anti-racism messages, a federal class-action lawsuit for withholding employee bonuses to maximize profit, and unlawfully collecting employee fingerprints. The retailer was critisized in 2019 for cutting hours on a mass scale after pressure to raise their hourly wage to $15, defeating the purpose of paying a living wage. Oxfam's "Behind the Barcode" initiative rated Whole Foods an 8% for their policies and practices in their labor rights in supply chains, and the company scored a 76% on their 2019 Corporate Sustainability Report. Their meat is Global Animal Partnership certified.

Hobby Lobby is a corporate arts and crafts retailer. They are well known for their supreme court case Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, Inc. which allows closely held corporations to restrict resources on employees' medical insurance that conflict with the employer's religious beliefs. Hobby Lobby requires its employees to sign a binding arbitration agreement that waves the employees' right to bring workplace violations and disputes to court. In 2017, legal action was taken by employees to sue Hobby Lobby to pay back uncompensated overtime wages. Transparency is lacking in their environmental and animal welfare practices, and there is no Corporate Sustainability Report ranking due to lack of data available.They did score a 6.6/10 on Glassdoor for employee labor satisfaction. They are additionally not third party certified by organizations that monitor their labor and sustainability claims. Hobby Lobby was charged for illegally importing ancient artifacts for their "Museum of the Bible" exhibit, in which they paid a fine of $3 million and the artifacts were later returned to Iraq.

Michaels arts & crafts is a member of Open to All, a national public education campaign against discrimination, and the Boys and Girls Clubs of America & Canada to support young peoples'  access to pathways to success. They score a 25/100 on CSRHub's Corporate Sustainability Report and report their 2020 Sustainability Report on their website. They scored a 6.4/10 on Glassdoor for their employee labor satisfaction. Over 45% of Michaels stores' waste was recycled in 2019. Michaels is Great Place to Work - Certified for 2019-2020. They have a charity "Michaels CARES" that helps employees with grants to recover from a difficult event such as a natural disaster or family loss. They also offer veteran employment, offer employes adoption benefits, tuition reimbursement, and discounts for veterans, senior, and teachers. Their sustainability measures including using LEED-certified light bulbs and offering toxic disposal for some of their products reflect minimal effort to compete with more sustainable corporate practices. They additionally lack transparency about where they source their animal products.

Cuddle Clones is a pet-focused, hand-made plush shop that donates to animal welfare shelters and organizations, and provides 3 meals and a toy to a shelter pet with every purchase. These organizations are listed on their website and are traceable. The plushes are made in China’s Guangdong province at a 100%-owned small workshop, where they are in close proximity to local materials they source, mainly polyester and acrylic, and the shop claims to source only synthetic materials. They do not disclose their sustainability measures or if they pay a living wage, and the only information available is on their website, which is not third-party certified.

Ali Express is owned by their sister company, Alibaba (2.3). They have been accused of credit card fraud, counterfeit products and missing items, which cannot be traced because the sellers remain anonymous. Their low transparency makes it difficult to understand from an ethical perspective, however it is widely acknowledged that the company is comparable to Amazon and exploits laborers by promoting excessive overtime culture in favor of corporate revenue.
The Doggy Treat is a family-owned, Black-owned business specializing in USA-made dog treats. They ship in compostable and recyclable packaging.

Coach scored a 100% on the Human Rights Campaign's Corporate Equality Index, a 24% on the Human Rights Benchmark, a 28% in Forest 500 on their steps to eradicate deforestation in their practices, a 19/100 on the Fashion Transparency Index, and a 21/100 by S&P Global for their corporate sustainability. Coach's CEO is paid 486 times the median employee wage. They were also rated a D on the Carbon Discosure Project, who score their disclosure, awareness, management, and leadership in response to reducing climate change in their supply chain. Coach additionally scored a 0/19.5 in their traceability of sourcing sustainable cotton by Rank a Brand. In 2020, they scored a 5.4/100 on their environmental management and water pollution in Chinese supply chains. In 2018, numerous labor law violations were found in their main factory in China. They are a partner of the Leather Working Group that ensures compliance and sustainability in their tannery practices, and are a Sustainable Apparel Coalition member. In 2019, As You Sow scored Coach's conflict mineral mining practices at a 50%, which is an adequate score for the industry.

Label By Three is a small POC-owned vegan clothing shop that sources locally and handmakes their apparel from deadstock fabrics that are upcycled into new clothing. They ship in 100% post-consumer and recyclable packaging, and they pay their employees a living wage.

Come Back As A Flower, or CBAAF is a POC-owned small apparel business that uses 100% recycled cotton, and is based in Los Angeles where materials are sourced locally. It is not transparent whether their apparel is made in an ethical facility that pays a living wage. They do not use animal products.

Sami Miro Vintage is a POC and woman-owned small buisness specializing in sustainable upcycled clothing. They do not use animal products in their line, and minimize waste by operating and sourcing locally in Los Angeles.

Pact is a Fair Trade certified and Global Organic Textile Standard certified apparel brand. They use eco-friendly materials like organic cotton in their products, and they use wool. They host a donation program called "Give Back Box" that receives donated clothing to go to nonprofits that need them. Pact ships in minimal packaging and offers a Carbon neutral shipping option.

Dear Survivor is a small business dedicated to paying it forward to communities affected by sex trafficking. They donated over $20,000 to Generate Hope, an organization helping women rebuild their lives after trafficking. They use ethically sourced materials, and theiir leather and metal objects are made from scraps to give them a new life, and their items are ships in recyclable packaging.

Cerer is a small clothing brand focused on sustainability. They are a 1% for the Planet member, and ships in recycled, zero-waste packaging. They do not disclose if their workers are treated fairly and if they are paid a living wage.
Factory Direct Craft lacks transparency about how their employees are treated and paid, where they source their products from, their sustainability measures or their social involvement.

Alter Eco is an organic chocolatier listed as a brand using ethically sourced cocoa by Slave Free Chocolate, scores an A rating on Green America's 2019 Chocolate Scorecard for sourcing 100% FairTrade cocoa that is fully traceable, and are BCorp certified. They do not use palm oil in their products, and they use compostable packaging. They do use grass-fed milk in their products, but so sell some plant-based items. Their 2019 Sustainability Report is publicly available on their website.

Endangered Species chocolate scores an A rating on Green America's 2019 Chocolate Scorecard for sourcing 100% FairTrade cocoa that is fully traceable. They donate 10% of profits to animals, habitat and humanity, and are NonGMO Project Verified. Their 2019 Impact Report is transparent and available publicly on their website where they share information about the conservation projects they partner with. They do not use palm oil. Endangered Species was listed as a chocolatier using ethically sourced cocoa by Slave Free Chocolate. Most of their chocolate is labeled certified vegan.

Tony's Chocolonely is listed as a chocolatier using ethically sourced cocoa by Slave Free Chocolate, and has a business model that prioritizes 0% profit in favor of using their revenue for greater impact in the field of slave-free chocolate. Their packaging is recyclable, and they offset their Carbon footprint through the JustDiggit project. Does use dairy in their chocolate.
UnReal is a NonGMO Project certified chocolate and candy brand. They use FairTrade ingredients and sell mostly vegan products.

Justin's is Rainforest Alliance certified and Non GMO Project certified. They partner with the Xerces Society and People & Pollinators Action Network to support pollinator conservation. They are transparent with their palm oil sourcing practices on their website and uses either 100% Organic sustainable palm oil or RSPO certified palm oil. They use wind power in their manufacturing practices. Their peanut butter cups are FairTrade certified, but it is unclear if this is true for all of their products.

Divine is a chocolatier committed to empowering women in Ghana and listed as using ethically sourced cocoa by Slave Free Chocolate, and score an A rating on Green America's 2019 Chocolate Scorecard for sourcing 100% FairTrade cocoa that is fully traceable. They are Non GMO Project certified, and do not use palm oil.

Equal Exchange is a worker-owned cooperative that They are listed as a chocolatier using ethically sourced cocoa by Slave Free Chocolate, and score an A rating on Green America's 2019 Chocolate Scorecard for sourcing 100% FairTrade cocoa that is fully traceable.

They are listed as a chocolatier using ethically sourced cocoa by Slave Free Chocolate, and score an A rating on Green America's 2019 Chocolate Scorecard for sourcing 100% FairTrade cocoa that is fully traceable. Their website transparently shows their 2019 Impact Report, and they are certified Organic and Fair For Life. They give their farmers a stable price to circumvent the volatility of the cocoa market, incentivising farmers to maintain a quality crop and support their families every year. They use dairy in their products, but offer vegan varieties.
Ocho is a FairTrade Certified, Organic, Certified Vegan, and certified CCOF chocolate company.
Lake Champlain chocolates are FairTrade certified and BCorp certified.
Tcho is listed as a chocolatier using ethically sourced cocoa by Slave Free Chocolate, and uses a portion of FairTrade ingredients.
